dimension: 4 7/8 x 11 x 7 in. (12.38 x 27.94 x 17.78 cm) (outer frame)
medium:
Tz'u-chou ware
Slip-covered stoneware with incised floral decor against a "fish roe" ground
title: Pillow
text: This bean-shaped head-rest represents a sub-group of Tz'u-chou ware, mainly pillows whose floral designs were created by incising through a white slip and setting them off against a punch marked, so-called "fish-roe" ground. Tz'u-chou wares with incised designs on a ground of closely stamped rings like this example were produced from the tenth to early twelfth century. The ring-punch ground design was most likely influenced by T'ang dynasty (618-906) metalwork wherein ring-punched grounds were used to set off major design motifs in gold and silver vessels.
description: Tz\'u-chou pillow, bean-shaped with leaf design, incised against punch-mark ground on white slip coating; stoneware.
